context: The Finnish word 'äiti' means mother or mom in English. It is a common noun used to refer to one's female parent. In the examples, 'Minun äiti on lääkäri' translates to 'My mother is a doctor', 'Äiti tekee ruokaa joka päivä' means 'Mother makes food every day', and 'Heidän äitinsä tulee huomenna' translates to 'Their mother is coming tomorrow'. Note that when the word is in the genitive case (possessive), it becomes 'äidin' as seen in 'Minun äiti' where 'minun' means 'my'.
